questions.correct_answer: D. Micro dendritic epithelial ulcers may be present
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Micro dendritic epithelial ulcers may be present The image shows Herpes zoster ophthalmicus. Presents with micro dendritic epithelial ulcers, which are also called pseudo dendritic ulcers as they lack terminal knobs.

Highyeild:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is an acute infection of the Gasserian ganglion of the fifth cranial nerve by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) involving the first (ophthalmic) division. It constitutes approximately 10% of all cases of herpes zoster. Herpes zoster occurs more commonly in immunocompromised individuals. Aetiology Varicella-zoster virus. It is a DNA virus and produces acidophilic intranuclear inclusion bodies. It is neurotropic in nature. Pathogenesis . The infection is contracted in childhood, which manifests chickenpox, and the child develops immunity. The virus then remains dormant in the sensory ganglion of the trigeminal nerve. lt is thought that, usually in elderly people, though (can occur at any age) with depressed cellular immunity, the virus reactivates, replicates, and travels down along one or more of the branches of the ophthalmic division of the fifth nerve to produce cutaneous and ocular lesions. The people, particularly prone to herpes zoster ophthalmicus, are the elderly with depressed cellular immunity, for example, those suffering from, disseminated TB, cancer, leukemia, AIDS or immunocompromised organs. Transplant recipient and lymphoma (Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin) Clinical features: Clinical phases of H. zoster ophthalmicus are: Hutchinson 's rule, which implies that ocular involvement is frequent if the side or tip of the nose presents vesicles (cutaneous involvement of nasociliary nerve), is useful but not infallible. • Lesions are strictly limited to one side of the midline of the head. Ocular complications occur in about 50% of cases of herpes zoster ophthalmicus. The frontal nerve is more frequently affected than the lacrimal and nasociliary nerves in herpes zoster ophthalmicus. Acute phase lesions , which may totally resolve within a few weeks. Chronic phase lesions, which may persist for years. Relapsing phase lesions , where acute or chronic lesions reappear sometimes years later. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus presents with Conjunctivitis Epithelial keratitis Nummular keratitis Disciform keratitis Scleritis Iridocyclitis Treatment: Systemic therapy for herpes zoster Antivirals: Acyclovir in a dose of 800 mg 5 times a day for 10 days, or • Valaciclovir in a dose of SOOTDS for LO days. Analgesics. Pain during the first 2 weeks of an attack is very severe and should be treated by analgesics such as a combination of mefenamic acid and paracetamol pentazocine, or even pethidine ( when very severe). Systemic steroids. They appear to inhibit development of postherpetic neuralgia when given in high doses. Steroids are commonly recommended in cases developing neurological complications such as third nerve palsy and optic neuritis. Cimetidine in a dose of 300 mg QTD for 2-3 weeks starting within 48-72 hours of onset has also been shown to reduce pain and pruritus in acute zoster, presumably by histamine blockade. Amitriptyline should be used to relieve the accompanying depression in the acute phase. Local therapy for skin lesions Antibiotic-corticosteroid skin ointment No calamine lotion. Cool zinc calamine application, as advocated earlier, is better avoided, as it promotes crust formation. Local therapy for ocular lesions Topical steroid eye drops 4 times a day. Cycloplegics such as cyclopentolate eye drops 8D or atropine eye ointment OD. Topical acyclovir 3% eye ointment should be instilled 5 limes a day for about 2 weeks. To prevent secondary infections topical antibiotics are used.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with complaints of irritation and lacrimation in right eye. Signs show punctate epithelial keratitis and a lesion in cornea as shown in image. He gives a history of malarial infection 15 days ago. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Recurrent ocular herpes The lesion shown is a dendritic ulcer, which is most common in recurrent epithelial keratitis from recurrent ocular herpes. The patient is an adult A history of malaria or any stress stimuli activates the virus.

Highyeild:

Recurrent Ocular Herpes The virus, which lies dormant in the trigeminal ganglion , periodically reactivates and replicates. The reactivated virus in enveloped infectious form travels down along the trigeminal nerve to cause recurrent infection. The recurrent herpetic ocular infection is not associated with systemic features and typically is a unilateral disease. Predisposing stress stimuli that trigger an attack of herpetic keratitis include fevers such as malaria, flu, exposure to ultraviolet rays, general ill health, emotional or physical exhaustion, mild trauma, menstrual stress following administration of topical or systemic steroids, and immunosuppressive agents. Epithelial keratitis Symptoms: of epithelial HSV keratitis include redness, pain, photophobia, tearing and decreased vision. Sign: Three distinct patterns of epithelial keratitis seen are: punctate epithelial keratitis (fine or coarse superficial punctate lesions) , dendritic ulcer: Dendritic ulcer is a typical and most common lesion of recurrent epithelial keratitis. The ulcer is of an irregular, zigzag Linear branching shape. The branches are generally knobbed at the ends, and geographical ulcer ( sometimes, the branches of dendritic ulcer enlarge and coalesce to form a large epithelial ulcer with a 'geographic' or 'amoeboid' configuration, hence the name). Stromal keratitis Disciform keratitis pathogenesis . It occurs due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to the HSV antigen. Primarily, endotheliitis occurs. Endothelial damage results in disciform corneal stromal oedema due to an imbibition of aqueous humour. Symptoms include photophobia, mild-to-moderate ocular discomfort, and a reduction in visual acuity. Disciform keratitis is characterized by: Focal disc-shaped patch of stromal oedema without necrosis, usually with an intact epithelium. Folds in Descemet's membrane, arc after percent. Keratic precipitates a.re seen under the round area of stromal edema. Ring of stromal infiltrate (Wessley immune ring) may be present surrounding the stromal oedema. It signifies the junction between viral antigen and host antibody. Corneal sensations are diminished. Intraocular pressure (IOP) may be raised despite only mild anterior uveitis due to trabeculitis. In severe cases, anterior uveitis may be marked. Treatment : 3% Acyclovir 5 times per day Topical steroids are CI as they can cause geographic ulcer Disciform keratitis presents with dysfunction of endothelium leading to central and epithelial edema Rx- topical steroids and topical antiviral Necrotizing stromal keratitis due to viral activation within stroma Rx- oral antivirals Metaherpatic keratitis due to failure of re epithelialization resulting from corneal anesthesia caused by denervation or drug toxicity Rx - bandage soft contact lenses, topical lubricants

questions.text: Corneal melts without inflammation in which condition –
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratomalacia Keratomalacia is an eye disorder that involves drying and clouding of the cornea (the clear layer in front of the iris and pupil) due to vitamin A deficiency .Night blindness is an early symptom. Blindness can eventually develop.

Highyeild:

Keratomalacia Keratomalacia is often preceded by an episode of infection: diarrhea and respiratory infection are common precipitating factors. Prospective studies also show that common childhood infections, including diarrhea, respiratory illness, measles, and chickenpox, induce hypovitaminosis A. During acute infection, not only is the food intake reduced but metabolic alterations are also known to occur. These include decreased absorption of vitamin A, impaired retinol transport, and increased renal excretion. Slow normalization of these mechanisms coupled with low dietary intake of vitamin A during the acute phase and recovery lead to VAD. Parasitic infections like ascariasis and giardiasis also aggravate VAD. Intestinal worms may directly compete for uptake of vitamin A, besides their more general impact on health by suppressing appetite.

Gout : The most common ocular abnormality described in patients with gout is a red eye, usually bilateral, caused by conjunctival and episcleral hyperemic vessels. Option: B . Sarcoidosis : Ocular signs suggestive for ocular sarcoidosis Mutton-fat keratic precipitates and/or iris nodules. Trabecular meshwork nodules and/or tent-shaped peripheral anterior synechiae. Snowballs or string of pearls in the vitreous. Active or inactive multiple chorioretinal peripheral lesions Option: D. Rheumatoid arthritis : Ocular manifestations of RA include dry eye syndrome, episcleritis, scleritis, and PUK. The most vision-threatening sequelae include corneal perforation or ruptured globe from scleritis, particularly scleromalacia perforans.

questions.text: This clinical Image is characteristically seen in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes Simplex Keratitis Patients with HSV keratitis may complain of the following: Pain Photophobia Blurred vision Tearing Redness The earliest sign of active viral replication in the corneal epithelium is the development of small, raised, clear vesicles. Dendritic ulcers are the most common presentation of HSV keratitis. Prominent features of a dendritic ulcer include a linear branching pattern with terminal bulbs at the ends of the branches, swollen epithelial borders of the branches, and central ulceration through the basement membrane. The earliest signs of neurotrophic keratopathy include an irregular corneal surface and punctate epithelial erosions. These erosions may progress to a persistent epithelial defect and eventual stromal ulceration. Necrotizing stromal keratitis is characterized by dense stromal infiltrate, ulceration, and necrosis. Immune stromal keratitis (ISK) may present clinically with focal, multifocal, or diffuse cellular infiltrates; immune rings; neovascularization; or ghost vessels at any level of the cornea.
